p: In 2002, the outbreak of SARS in Guangdong Province, China led to the discovery of SARS‐CoV, a highly pathogenic CoV, as the causative pathogen of the epidemic [ 7]. Although the virus is primarily a respiratory pathogen, there are reports of neurological manifestations, such as epileptic seizures and encephalitis, that may suggest a CNS involvement of the infection [ 8, 9] (Table 1). Complementing these reports, post‐mortem neuropathological studies have detected the SARS‐CoV N protein and RNA polymerase gene fragment in neurons of infected patients and pathological changes such as brain tissue edema and vasculitis of cerebral veins [ 10].
